description.narrative: 1.Number of Peace and Development Councils established and effective in their function

comment.narrative: No functioning dialogue mechanism exist

1.1 5 additional CBRM councils functional, including in Katila 1.2 50 % of community members have access to CBRMs of which at least 40% are female and vulnerable youth. 2.1 5 community based management mechanisms for natural resources established 2.2 At least 5 community social service infrastructure rehabilitated/ constructed 2.3 50 % of community members stating an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities through basic services 3.1 3 collective interactions of conflict resolution mechanisms with state and regional level mechanisms 3.2 3 collective interactions of conflict resolutions mechanisms with higher level mechanism

1.1 Target exceeded. A total of 6 CBRMs were established in Q1 and Q2 of 2015, including in Katila. 1.2 Target exceeded. CBRMs are accessible by the around 26,700 community members. This represents about 90 % of community members in the targeted communities. Perception survey conducted in Mukjar indicated that 90% of community members have access to CBRMS in the project target areas of which 60% are female. (source perception survey) 2.1Target achieved.Three (3) Joint Management Committees (JMC) have been established; one for managing the water well in Mukjar, one for managing the community farm of Kormondo and one for hand dug well in Birgi return village. Two more mechanisms are planned to be established before the end of the year. 2.2 Target exceeded. Total of seven Social service infrastructures have been established / rehabilitated including Two (2) new hand dug wells established in Bergi and Mukjar and one (1) hand dug well in Mukjar, One (1) Livelihood Centre Constructed in Mukjar and one Women Peace Centre at Katilla locality has been constructed, One (1) water station has rehabilitated in Damba village in Kubum Locality and One (1) bakery for food processing was established. 2.3 Target achieved. According to the perception survey conducted in September 2015, 84 % of the community members stated that there is an increase in the interaction between the communities due to establishment of the water points, vegetable farms, distribution of incomes generating sources and tools. 3.1 Target achieved. In 2015, 4 events for collective interaction of conflict resolution mechanisms included: One (1) consultative meeting was held with the Centre for Peace and Development of the University of Nyala and Three (3) workshops on Conflict analysis, Peace building and Conflict Transformation were conducted in Nyala, El Fasher and Zalingei. 3.2 Target achieved.Three Training of Trainer (TOT) workshops on Peacebuilding and Conflict Management and Transformation were con

title.narrative: Planning and Public Expenditure Management (PPEM) Darfur

description.narrative: The project aims at improving the State governments capacity to collect taxes and prioritize public expenditures. Improved public expenditure management with strengthened planning capacity will be instrumental in optimising delivery of public services.

The project aims at improving the State governments capacity to collect taxes and prioritize public expenditures. Improved public expenditure management with strengthened planning capacity will be instrumental in optimising delivery of public services.
seat of a first-order administrative division
Accountability - local government finance
1. Increase in revenue collection 2. Number of institutions at state and locality level with computerized payroll system 3. Number of SSP reviewed and prioritized for three states

comment.narrative: 1. Local revenue too low amounting to only 15% (ND), 20% (SD) and 3.5% (WD) of total revenue receipts in 2009 (ND) and 2010 (SD & WD). 2. No Standard guidelines for revenue collection and reporting in place. 3. Budget departments facing difficulties to apply the GFS as it was imposed from the national Government without provision of requisite training. 4. Payroll is done manually resulting in errors and huge payroll arrears. 5. Strategic planning is still at its infancy and therefore needs strengthening.

Output 1 10% increase in local revenue collection 100 booklets/guidelines developed & distributed to localities 10 teams applying GFS system in selected localities for the year
Output 2 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities prepare GFS conforming budget 90 staff from line ministries and pilot localities trained on GFS.
Output 3 20% of line ministries and 20% of localities level decrease in reporting inconsistencies 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities apply the adopted GFS system
Output 4 5 State Ministries of Finance equipped with computerized payroll system and routinely using it 1 audit conducted 20% decrease in payroll arrears
Output 5 Guide for strategic planning developed & 100 copies distributed 200 staff at state and locality levels trained on strategic planning process.
Two preliminary audits were undertaken in West and South Darfur

1. Change in levels and quality of coordination of aid policy between government concerned departments (will be monitored through conducting aid policy coordination studies) 2. Establishment of sustainable government/development partners comprehensive dialogue forum on aid policy and coordination

comment.narrative:
Baseline output1: 1. Following the government restructure in 2012, the government Directorates responsible for aid management and coordination have been organized according to new institutional and coordination set up in the government. 2. Capacities of government officials responsible for aid management and coordination needs to be further developed to manage aid coordination after government restructuring 3. No comprehensive capacity assessment has been carried out for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination. 4. No comprehensive capacity development plan has been developed and implemented for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination
Baseline Output2: 1. SAID project module has been completed successfully. 2. SAID Fund Expectation module has been completed. 3. SAID programme and aid effectiveness modules have not been completed 4. Aid M&E and information systems are not integrated and harmonized
Baseline Output3:
1. Government aid policy coordination between relevant directorates of the MoFNE (budget, policies, aid management and coordination and development directorates) needs strengthening especially after the government restructuring 2. There are no sufficient aid dialogue and coordination structures including government and development partners 3. A draft Sudan Aid Strategy has been formulated

title.narrative: Promoting Rule of Law and Access to Justice in Sudan

description.narrative: This project aims to improve the delivery of justice and security services to increase access to justice for all, especially the poor, vulnerable and marginalized groups.
This project aims to improve the delivery of justice and security services to increase access to justice for all, especially the poor, vulnerable and marginalized groups.

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

description.narrative:
1.1 # of criminal justice forums established and frequency of meetings 1.2 # justice strategy plans roll out for the prosecutor 1.3 # of joint training sessions conducted on the human rights approach for justice sector officials 1.4 # of joint training sessions conducted on strategic planning processes for justice sector officials 1.5 # of joint training sessions on budgeting processes conducted for justice sector officials # of legal aid provider clients (individual and communities) disaggregated by gender (% of women) assisted with legal aid counselling 1.2.1: # of refresher courses for GoS prisons officers on human rights approach to prisons management and # of training courses for newly recruited prisons officers for a total of # participants 1.2.2: # of water tanks constructed to address water needs of selected prisons 1.2.3: #of vocational and livelihood skills training workshops established and type of tools and equipment procured 1.3.1. .#of capacity development trainings, including strategic planning conducted for police officers 1.3.2. #civilian oversight mechanisms in place 1.4.1: #of capacity development trainings conducted to Sudan National Human Rights Commission staff and key stakeholders 1.4.2: New committee in Darfur established and strategic priorities for Darfur defined 1.5.1. # of relevant government officials have improved their knowledge in human rights, and improved the implementation of Sudan obligations under human rights treaties 1.5. 2. comment.narrative: 1. Two criminal justice forums established at regional level (one in Darfur and one in eastern Sudan) and quarterly meetings held 2. 100 complaints received and no data on caseload age 3. No office existing outside of Khartoum 4. 300 representatives of the judiciary, prosecutors, police and prison staff and social workers trained in human rights and 47 social workers 5. 82 parliamentarians and legal advisors trained on importance of law reform for child law and womens law 6. UPR action Plan for the UPR process developed 7. 30% of people report high confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions overall; 20% women report high confidence; 22% reported easy access (2013) 8. 4 Legal aid network (LAN) organizations and 4 JCCs in Darfur were fully functional and active during 2013 9. Two legal aid desks established in the selected prisons in Darfur but not yet effectively functional 10. There is little knowledge on the alternative dispute resolution mechanisms 11.Limited monitoring visits to support project implementation by staff

1. Two criminal justice forums established at regional level (one in Darfur and one in eastern Sudan) and quarterly meetings held 2. 6 strategic planning sessions provided to selected justice sector institutions 3. 70% of citizens report confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions 4. 6 refresher courses for GoS prisons officers on human rights approach to prisons management and 6 training courses for newly recruited prisons officers conducted in all five Darfur states for 300 participants 5. 1 underground water tank (250,000 liters) and 1 elevated water tank (40,000 liters) constructed at Shallah Federal Prison in El Fasher to address water needs 6. 6 vocational and livelihood skills training workshops established and tools and equipment for welding and metal works, carpentry, masonry, auto-mechanics, and tailoring procured in 6 Darfur prisons (Shallah Federal Prison in El Fasher; Kheir Khanaga Women Prison in El Fasher; Central Prison in Nyala; Ardamata Prison in El Geneina; Zalingei Prison; and El Daein Prison 7. # senior police management and leadership M/F trained on strategic planning 8. Civilian Oversight Mechanisms drafted through 2 consultations and workshops 9. Special committee on Darfur in place and strategic priorities for Darfur established 10. 200 relevant government officials have improved their human rights knowledge and enhanced the implementation of Sudan obligations under human Rights treaties 11. Progress towards revision of 4 laws (Child Act, Press Act, Criminal Act and law related to womens rights) 12. Sets of indicators and timelines to monitor UPR implementation progress developed and included into the UPR Action Plan 13. 50% report high confidence overall; 30% women report high confidence; 30% report easy access. 14. Target: 300 clients (30% women) assisted with legal aid counselling at the 8 existing JCCs across Darfur and 150 clients in eastern Sudan 15. 10 NGOs and CBOs participating in access to justice trainings

1) Overall progress for output 1: improve justice, security and human rights provided by state actors through more effective, equitable and timely protection services: Implementation of activities to improve the capacity of Justice, Security and human Rights Institutions is progressing well. Vocational training were developed and delivered with the participation of various stakeholders including UNAMID, Police and Prison Section with government ministries (Prosecutor, Prison and Police). Implementation of the 5 Year Strategic plan for prison development is progressing well (17F & 113M) prison officers benefited from Human rights approach to prisons management for prison officers. Fair trial and legal aid related principles have been incorporated into training models for prosecutors and lawyers (123F & 267M). Similarly, management and leadership skills, criminal investigation, with focus SGBV were delivered to police officers (8F & 56M). To increase the extension of police service Community policing volunteers training models were delivered with the participation of IDPs, community leaders, women groups, youth (445F & 356M). Special efforts have also been made improve Darfur Transitional Justice institutions to fight impunity and promote reconciliation with a Witness and Victims Protection Strategy along with UNAMID Human Rights Section. Implementation of UPR Recommendations is progressing well. Data collection around the implementation of UPR is showing that 85% of UPR Recommendations have been implemented, with the amendment of Criminal Law, Election Law and the adoption of Human Trafficking Law and Access to Information Law and Regulation of Refugees Law. Access to legal aid and protection for vulnerable groups strengthened
2) Overall progress for Output 2: Access to legal aid and protection for vulnerable groups strengthened : With the goal of scaling up the provision of legal aid and enhance legal awareness efforts in multiple provinces in five Darfur States a

1. One additional criminal justice forum established at state level 2. One training course for newly recruited prisons officers conducted in North Darfur state for 50 prison officers 3. At least 50 in-mates provided with vocational skills training in 3 Prisons in Darfur 4. Two water tanks constructed at Shallah prison to deliver reliable and safe water supply at Shallah Prison 5. 2000 persons reached with human rights awareness raising in the 4 JCCs 6. 300 cases (30% women) mediated at the 4 existing JCCs across Darfur 7. UNDP and UNAMID teams in place with required capacities to support implementation 8. Quarterly consultative stakeholders meetings held for Khartoum level stakeholders and monthly meetings for Darfur based stakeholders. Ad hoc stakeholders meetings can also be scheduled if necessary 9. Project reports submitted timely (bi annual) and on agreed upon templates 10. Risks and issues updated quarterly in Atlas, and lessons learned documented at the end of the project

1. Training course for 50 prisons officers conducted and completed in North Darfur (18 females and 32 males) 2. Three workshops in North, South and West Darfur provided with the necessary tools and equipment. 3. Risks updated regularly 4. 50%. Planning meetings have been held to discuss the composition and functioning of the forums in Darfur. Launch of the Criminal Justice forum in Central Darfur is on track

title.narrative: Strengthening the Capacity of the Sudan National Human R

description.narrative: Strengthening the Capacity of the Sudan National Human Rights Commission

The projects main objective is to support the SNHRC in the development of its operational, technical and legal capacities to become a cornerstone within Sudans national human rights protection system in line with the Paris Principles.

Output 1 Complaints management infrastructure strengthned
Indicators: 4.1. Mandate of Complaints committee reviewed/modified and Job classification of secretary reclassified as Registrar 4.2: Extent to which workflow design for Case management is completed for entire lifecycle of complaints 4:3: Development of operational policies for complaints management established 4.4: Development of Manuals (tools) for intake, investigations, referrals, reporting, urgent cases, confidentiality, and systemic cases . 4.5: Feasibility study developed/finalized on viable options for automated CM system 4.6: Caseload (quantity) of received is disaggerated equaly on gender baisis 4.7 . Duration of case processing by calaneder days. Output 5: Engagement in Darfur supported
Output 2: Engagement in Darfur supported
Indicators
2. 1: New committee on Darfur established and strategic priorities for Darfur defined 2.2: workshops on joint human rights cooperation framework conducted 23: of meetings of Darfur human rights forum 2.4: of meetings of State human rights sub-forums at the local level to address key human rights concerns
Indicators: output 3 Commissioners and staff capacity to perform respective functions through the delivery of targeted trainings and professional development:
3.1. # of staff trained on new policies and software; protection and promotion 3.2 # operational policies developed covering all areas of NHRI

comment.narrative:
1.1 Complaints Committee established and has begun working, but administrative staff acts as intake officer and registrar 1.2: There is no structured workflow for case management life cycle in SNHRC 1.3: No complaints management manual 1.4: No feasibility study has been conducted 1,5 No automated case management system in place 1.6 Gender disaggregation of caseload is currently 20% female and 80% males cases 1.7 . TBC
Baseline out 2:
2.1: No committee on Darfur established and strategic priorities for Darfur not defined 2.2: No engagement of SNHRC in joint human rights cooperation framework 2.3: Zero 2.4: No systematic engagement or activities in Darfur
Baseline output3:
3.1. Zero staff trained 3.2. Zero operational policy is in place

4.1: Complaints committee reviewed to assumes oversight and governance role; position of registrar established 4.2: Complaints management process flow is designed for entire case management life cycle 4.3: Caseload processing manuals are developed for intake, investigations, referrals, reporting, urgent cases, confidentiality, and systemic cases 4..4 Feasibility study on CM finalized 4.5 Automated case management system installed and in place 4.6 Gender disaggregation of caseload become 50% female and 50% males cases 4.7 . TBE
Targets for Output 2:
2.1: Special committee on Darfur in place and Strategic priorities for Darfur set 2: 2 One workshop on joint human rights cooperation framework 2.3 Four meetings of the Darfur Human Rights Forum with Gos, ACHR, SNHRC, donors, UN agencies, CSOs 2.4: Ten meetings at the local level to address key human rights concerns
Targets for Output 3:
3.1. All staff (112 staff 40% of whom are females ) received training on core operational policies; At least 10 trainings courses conducted on case management. 3.2. TBC (Key internal administrative and operational policies in place)

Overall progress of output 4: Complaint Management infrastructure strengthened: internal regulations of the Complaints Committee revised with oversight and governance role of the Complaints Committee, with Complaints Manual and standard forms covering the management process for the entire life cycle of a case have been developed. In order to increase the visibility of the SNHRC and of the Complaints Committee in particular, an outreach programme was organized for 70 people, including over 10 members of the media.
Overall Progress of Output 5 Engagement in Darfur: Workshop was organized in Khartoum with representatives from Darfur, UNAMID Human rights Section to establish the new Committee on Darfur and define its road map or strategic plan for the opening of the SNHRC in Darfur, and arrangements are underway to launch the Darfur Branch in December
Overall Progress of output 6: Commissioners and staff capacity to perform respective functions through the delivery of targeted training and professional developed: Significant results have been achieved in developing internal policies. A two-day training for the Commissioners and the staff of the Complaints Committee was held, and 7 operational policies were developed: 1 internal regulation and 3 key operational procedures for the Complaints Committee (as annexes to the Complaints Manual) ; 1 ethics/conflict of interest policy; 1 Staff Recruitment policy; 1 job description template

1.1 Feasibility study on Complaint Management finalized 1.2: Automated case management system installed and operational 1.3: Gender dis-aggregation of caseload (50% female and 50% males) 2.1: Special committee on Darfur in place and Strategic priorities for Darfur established 2. 2 One workshop on joint human rights cooperation framework 2.3 Four meetings of the Darfur Human Rights Forum with Gos, ACHR, SNHRC, donors, UN agencies, CSOs 2. 4: Four meetings at the local level to address key human rights concerns 3.1. All staff of the Commission (112 staff 40% of whom are females) received training on core operational policies; At least 8 training courses conducted on case management. 2.2. The feasibility of automated software assessed, and training conducted on new policies and software.

1. Automated case management system installed, 2. Special committee on Darfur established, 3. Feasibility study on Complaint Management finalized 4.. The feasibility of automated software assessed, and training conducted on new policies and software.

comment.narrative: This project has been established in line with UNDPs role as Managing Agent of the Sudan Common Humanitarian Fund/Country Based Pooled Fund as detailed in the CHF/CBPFs Terms of Reference and Accountability Framework . The project serves to channel allocations to NGOs for allocation round 1 / 2015 of the CHF. The total amount of resources allocated and transferred to NGOs in the Education Cluster for round 1 / 2015 in 2015 was USD 920,321.49

description.narrative: Provision of Protection to People in Need
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

comment.narrative: Since 2014, Sudan has witnessed an upsurge in conflict-induced displacement. In order to address the needs of these newly displaced people, as well as those people who have been displaced for a number of years, the protection sector has identified a number of priority areas to guide interventions in 2015. These interventions will be carried out in collaboration with the Government of Sudan, relevant protection institutions and humanitarian organisations.

This project has been established in line with UNDPs role as Managing Agent of the Sudan Common Humanitarian Fund/Country Based Pooled Fund as detailed in the CHF/CBPFs Terms of Reference and Accountability Framework . The project serves to channel allocations to NGOs for allocation round 1 / 2015 of the CHF. The total amount of resources allocated and transferred to NGOs in the Protection Cluster for round 1 / 2015 in 2015 was USD 2,685,114.15

description.narrative: Refugee Multi-Sector Support
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the

comment.narrative: Sudan hosts around 171,000 refugees and asylum seekers from a range of countries: Eritrea, Ethiopia, Chad, (CAR), the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Somalia and Syria. Around 92,000 live in eastern Sudan, another 32,000 in Khartoum, and around 45,000 in Darfur. Sudan also has over 90,000 Sudanese in Darfur who were previously refugees in Chad, and have now returned to their country of origin, but not all to their area of origin. Finally, there are also potentially 350,000 individuals of South Sudanese origin (of which around 40,000 reside in Khartoum) who had been living in Sudan prior to secession that did not flee conflict. They have an unclear legal status and so are potentially at risk of statelessness.

This project has been established in line with UNDPs role as Managing Agent of the Sudan Common Humanitarian Fund/Country Based Pooled Fund as detailed in the CHF/CBPFs Terms of Reference and Accountability Framework . The project serves to channel allocations to NGOs for allocation round 1 / 2015 of the CHF. The total amount of resources allocated and transferred to NGOs in the Refugee multi Sector Cluster for round 1 / 2015 in 2015 was USD 689,488.24
